rsbNotes.title: Josh 22–24
rsbNotes.text: 22:1–24:33 The book closes with three chapters about Israel’s faithfulness, following God’s faithfulness that has been the main subject so far (21:43–45 and note). The human response demanded by God’s remarkable grace is the recurring theme of the final chapters. Each chapter begins with Joshua summoning the people (22:1; 23:1–2; 24:1), and focuses on the faithfulness God now requires of them.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 24:1–28
rsbNotes.text: 24:1–28 At the end of his life, Joshua led Israel in a reaffirmation of the covenant, much as Moses did before he died (Deut. 32:46). As with Deuteronomy, there may be an analogy between this covenant renewal and the kind of treaties that were typically used to formalize relations between powerful sovereign nations and weaker client states (see Deuteronomy: Introduction). These treaties, called “suzerainty treaties,” commonly included elements like those found in Josh. 24, such as a historical prologue reviewing the care given by the powerful party to the client (vv. 2–13); a prohibition of any outside alliance (vv. 14, 23); and provision for a written document (vv. 25, 26). There are also significant differences between such ancient treaties and Josh. 24.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 24:1
rsbNotes.text:
24:1 Joshua gathered all the tribes. See 8:33–35; 23:2 and note.

Shechem. The very place where God had first promised the land to the descendants of Abraham (Gen. 12:6–7) is the place where the descendants assemble, having received the land. See note 8:30.

before God. This does not necessarily imply the movement of the tabernacle from Shiloh (19:51) to Shechem for the occasion. The presence of God was not restricted to the tabernacle (cf. 1 Kin. 8:27), just as His presence was not guaranteed by physical possession of the ark (1 Sam. 4:3–11).

rsbNotes.title: Josh 24:2
rsbNotes.text:
24:2 Thus says the Lord. Joshua speaks with the authority of Moses (Deut. 5:27) and of a prophet (Deut. 18:15–19).

beyond the Euphrates. The reference is presumably to Ur (Gen. 11:28) or Haran (Gen. 11:31).

other gods. The pagan beginning underlines the grace of God to which this history testifies, and provides the background for the exhortation in v. 14.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 24:3–13
rsbNotes.text: 24:3–13 The word of God to the people on this occasion is not a new word. The books of Genesis (vv. 2–4), Exodus (vv. 5–7), Numbers (vv. 8–10), and Joshua (vv. 11–13) are reviewed by way of rehearsing God’s dealings with the people since the time of Abraham, focusing on the gift of the land promised to Abraham and now received by his descendants. The review begins with a digest of Genesis from the promise to Abraham through the descent to Egypt (Gen. 11–50).

rsbNotes.title: Josh 24:3
rsbNotes.text:
24:3 Then I. God is the dominant subject of the verbs in vv. 3–13.

made his offspring many. The promise of many descendants to Abraham is a preeminent concern in Genesis (Gen. 12:2; 15:5; 17:2 and notes), and is related to God’s blessing on humanity in Gen. 1:26–18 (cf. Ex. 1:7 note).

rsbNotes.title: Josh 24:4
rsbNotes.text: 24:4 Jacob and Esau. The principle of divine election was clear in the choice of Jacob over Esau (Gen. 25:23; Rom. 9:11 and note). So also is the reality that God’s promises are often in apparent conflict with the immediate course of history. Jacob had to go to Egypt.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 24:5–7
rsbNotes.text: 24:5–7 Joshua’s summary of Exodus is remarkable for its failure to mention the giving of the Law at Mount Sinai. The account concentrates on the actions leading directly to occupation of the Promised Land.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 24:6
rsbNotes.text: 24:6 Red Sea. See note Ex. 13:18.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 24:7
rsbNotes.text:
24:7 your eyes saw. The people of Joshua’s day are spoken of as having participated in the redemptive events of the past. This emphasizes that they must see the goodness of God towards them not only in their personal experience, but also in the larger history of their people. See note 4:23, 24.

in the wilderness a long time. A few words summarize everything from the crossing of the sea to the arrival at the land. See note on vv. 5–7.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 24:8–10
rsbNotes.text: 24:8–10 Joshua’s summary of Numbers does not mention the rebellions that took place in the wilderness (Num. 14; 25), probably because the emphasis of his review is on the deeds of God.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 24:8
rsbNotes.text: 24:8 Amorites. See note 2:10.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 24:9
rsbNotes.text: 24:9 Balaam. See Num. 22–24; note on Josh. 13:22.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 24:10
rsbNotes.text: 24:10 Indeed, he blessed you. Balaam illustrates God’s complete power over those who would bring harm to His people.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 24:11
rsbNotes.text: 24:11 Amorites . . . Jebusites. See 3:10 and note.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 24:12
rsbNotes.text:
24:12 hornet. This is possibly a metaphor for sudden panic (2:9; 5:1; Ex. 23:28; Deut. 7:20).

not by your sword. The Israelites received the land as a gift that must not be understood as based on their own achievement (1:2 note; cf. Eph. 2:8).

rsbNotes.title: Josh 24:14
rsbNotes.text:
24:14 fear the Lord. See 4:24. This response is demanded by the history of God’s faithfulness to His promises in vv. 2–13. The fear of God is associated with knowledge of His grace and is fully compatible with love for Him (Deut. 10:12, 13; Ps. 130:4). Contrast 2:9, where the Canaanites fear God because of His coming judgment; and 7:5, where the Israelites experience His anger.

Put away the gods. This may refer literally to idols, or metaphorically to abandoning the gods they represent, or to both. The goodness of God to Israel (vv. 2–13) demands exclusive allegiance, summed up by the first commandment (Ex. 20:3).

the River. See note on v. 2.

and in Egypt. Israel’s idolatry in Egypt will be remembered by Ezekiel (20:7–10; 23:3–8, 19–21, 27).

rsbNotes.title: Josh 24:15
rsbNotes.text:
24:15 choose this day whom you will serve. There is some irony in offering a kind of choice after the Lord is rejected. The choice is between the gods Abraham left behind (vv. 2, 3) and the gods of the dispossessed Amorites (vv. 12; 2:10 note).

me and my house. See 6:25; 7:24; Acts 16:15.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 24:16–18
rsbNotes.text: 24:16–18 In response to the call of v. 14, the people repudiate other gods (v. 16), acknowledge the Lord’s goodness from the Exodus to the conquest, and conclude by promising obedience to the Lord.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 24:19
rsbNotes.text:
24:19 You are not able to serve the Lord. This paradoxical statement will all too soon be proved true (v. 31 note; 7:1–26 note; 23:12, 13 note; Judg. 2:7, 10–13; 2 Kin. 17:7–23; Deut. 31:16). It is based on the holiness of God, who cannot be approached casually (Ps. 15:1, 2; Eccl. 5:1, 2). Also, Joshua warns the people because he knows their rebelliousness himself (22:17 and note).

holy. Only a people separated from pagan ways (Lev. 18:3; 20:26) can serve the God who is holy, entirely separate from other gods (Lev. 19:2).

jealous. See Ex. 20:5 and note.

will not forgive. The transgressions in view here amount to the apostasy described in the following verse.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 24:20
rsbNotes.text: 24:20 he will turn. God’s dealing will change from grace to judgment (Gen. 6:7). In another sense God never changes (1 Sam. 15:29), since His promise has always included the threat of judgment (23:15; Gen. 6:6 and notes).

rsbNotes.title: Josh 24:21
rsbNotes.text: 24:21 we will serve the Lord. The people reject the possibility envisaged or predicted in v. 20.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 24:22
rsbNotes.text: 24:22 witnesses against yourselves. When they are accused of forsaking the Lord the case against them will be supported by their decision on this occasion.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 24:23
rsbNotes.text: 24:23 put away. See note on v. 14.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 24:25
rsbNotes.text:
24:25 made a covenant. Joshua formalized the relationship (cf. Gen. 15:18; Deut. 4:23; 29:1; see also notes on 3:3; 9:6).

statutes and rules. These would specify the content of Israel’s obedience to the Lord.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 24:26
rsbNotes.text:
24:26 Book of the Law of God. This is probably to be identified with the Book of the Law in 1:8; 8:31; 23:6.

terebinth. Compare Gen. 12:6; 35:4; Judg. 9:6.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 24:27
rsbNotes.text: 24:27 witness. Compare how the stones at Gilgal were to provide a testimony to what God had done (4:20–24 and note).

rsbNotes.title: Josh 24:28
rsbNotes.text: 24:28 every man to his inheritance. These words are an appropriate concluding note to the book that tells of God’s giving the promised inheritance to Israel. Similar words occur, after a considerably different period, at the end of the Book of Judges (Judg. 21:24). See note 1:6.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 24:29–33
rsbNotes.text: 24:29–33 The deaths of Joshua and Eleazar mark the end of the period that has been the subject of this book. Their burials, along with the burial of the bones of Joseph, in the land that is now Israel’s possession symbolizes God’s faithful fulfillment of His promises to the patriarchs.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 24:29
rsbNotes.text:
24:29 servant of the Lord. See note 1:1.

110. This age is the same as Joseph’s at his death (Gen. 50:22 and note). Such long lives signified God’s blessing (cf. Deut. 34:7).

rsbNotes.title: Josh 24:30
rsbNotes.text: 24:30 his own inheritance. See 19:49–50. Unlike Abraham, who had to purchase land for a burial plot (Gen. 23:4; cf. Gen. 33:19), Joshua is buried in his own land.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 24:31
rsbNotes.text: 24:31 Israel served the Lord all the days of Joshua. The faithfulness of the generation of Joshua and the elders is testimony to the Lord’s power in everything He had done for Israel. That such faithfulness would be so short-lived supports Joshua’s assertion in vv. 19–20 (notes; Judg. 2:7, 10–13).

rsbNotes.title: Josh 24:32
rsbNotes.text:
24:32 the bones of Joseph. The promise believed by Joseph (Gen. 50:24, 25 and notes) now comes to fulfillment.

Jacob bought. See Gen. 33:19. The new situation of owning the land is again contrasted with the time of the patriarchs, who had only the promise of it.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 24:33
rsbNotes.text:
24:33 Eleazar. See note 14:1.

Phinehas. See note 22:13.
